name: Crude oil, production mixture, at extraction
description: This unit process combines the U.S. crude oil production sources based on their percentage share in the U.S. crude oil production mix. The mix is made up of domestic on-shore, domestic off-shore, imported on-shore and imported off-shore sources. The process is for 1kg of crude oil to consumer. The crude oil mix is based on 2014 data from US Energy Information Administration (EIA), as well as data from National Oceanic and Atmospheric (NOAA), Sheridan 2006, and Bureau of Ocean Energy Management.
category: 21: Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extraction/2111: Oil and Gas Extraction

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This process is representative of the 2014 aggregate crude oil production mix based on percentages from EIA, 2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This process is representative of the U.S. crude oil production mix.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Crude oil extraction by percentage source. Includes onshore and offshore drilling into underground porous rock structures. Natural pressure or an automated pump bring oil to the surface. Once surfaced, oil is separated from water.
processDocumentation.inventoryMethodDescription: Attributional; gate to gate process. Compatible with TRACI.
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: Secondary data were used to determine the U.S. mix of crude oil.
processDocumentation.completenessDescription:
TREATMENT OF MISSING ENVIRONMENTAL DATA: Elementary flows are cut-off at less than 1% based on environmental relevance.
TREATMENT OF MISSING TECHNOSPHERE DATA: Miscellaneous materials and additives, capital equipment, facilities and infrastructure, space conditioning, and support personnel requirements are not included in this system process. No gaps have been identified in this dataset.
MASS BALANCE: The mass balance was calculated by a straight comparison of inputs and outputs
processDocumentation.dataSelectionDescription: The crude oil mix is based on 2014 data from US Energy Information Administration (EIA), as well as data from National Oceanic and Atmospheric (NOAA), Sheridan 2006, and Bureau of Ocean Energy Management.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset was used to model the aggregate crude oil extraction production mix process based on percentages from EIA, 2017.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS
The system boundary includes upstream burdens from incoming crude oil extraction sources and represents a consolidation of four extraction sources into one production mix. The following are excluded from the unit process boundary: miscellaneous materials and additives, capital equipment, facilities and infrastructure, space conditioning, and support personnel requirements.

DATA COLLECTION
Secondary data were collected from EIA, 2023.

UNCERTAINTY ESTIMATION
No uncertainty analysis was carried out due to the lack of uncertainty data or probability distributions for key parameters, which are often only available as single point estimates from NETL.

sources.name: Franklin Associates (2020). Cradle-to-Gate Life Cycle Analysis of Olefins

reviews.details: Internal review of data entry proofreading, mass balance verification and data documentation.

reviewers.name: Franklin Associates, A Division of ERG

processDocumentation.intendedApplication: The intended application for this process is for accounting purposes as described in Goal Situation C1 from the ILCD Handbook's Detailed Guidance. LCA studies with this intended application offer "purely descriptive documentation of the system under analysis (e.g., a product, sector or country), without being interested in any potential consequences on other parts of the economy.‚Äù The studies categorized under Goal Situation C1 do consider existing benefits outside the analyzed system such as recycling. A full inventory of environmental flows are included; thus this unit process can be used for a full range of LCIA impact categories. The target audience of this model includes LCA practitioners, industry, and the general public. For use as an average dataset accepted by the North American plastics/chemical industry. An inventory of environmental emission flows are included to the extent that the producers provided; thus this unit process can be used for a full range of LCIA impact categories. The original study results were analyzed using the TRACI LCIA factors.
processDocumentation.projectDescription: This project was funded by and submitted to the American Chemistry Council. These data are a background dataset used in the Cradle-to-Gate Life Cycle Analysis of Olefins report. Submitted to the American Chemistry Council (ACC). 2020.

dataGenerator.name: Franklin Associates, A Division of ERG

dataDocumentor.name: Franklin Associates, A Division of ERG

publication.name: Franklin Associates (2020). Cradle-to-Gate Life Cycle Analysis of Olefins
